(BCSE306L) 4 Search Algorithms Un-informed Search â–ªAgent can not estimate how far it is from Goal states. â–ª Breadth First Search (BFS) â–ª Depth First Search (DFS) â–ª Uniform cost search (Dijkstraâ€™s algo) â–ª Depth-limited and iterative deepening DFS â–ª F(n) = g(n) â–ª h(n) canâ€™t be estimated Informed Search â–ªAgent can estimate how far it is from Goal states. â–ª Greedy Best First Search â–ª A* Search â–ª F(n) = g(n) + h (n) 7/31/2025 Computer Science 5 Uninformed Search â–ªf(n) = g(n) + h (n) ; h(n) = 0 ( Unknown) â–ª Also known as "Blind Search." â–ªSearch strategies that explore a problem space without using domain-specific knowledge to guide them. â–ªThey rely only on the problem's structure: i) Initial State ii) Operators (Moves) iii) Goal Test â–ªKey Algorithms We'll Cover: BFS, DFS, DLS, IDS, and UCS. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 6 Breadth First Search (BFS) â–ª How it Works: Explores layer by layer, visiting all neighbors at the current depth before moving to the next level. â–ª Key Feature: Finds the shallowest solution. Guaranteed to be the shortest path if all step costs are equal. â–ª Use Cases: â–ª Social Networks: Finding "friends of friends.â€œ â–ª GPS: Finding a path with the fewest number of stops. â–ª Web Crawlers: Indexing web pages level by level from a source. â–ª Peer-to-Peer Networks: Locating the nearest peers in a network like BitTorrent. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 7 Depth First Search (DFS) â–ª How it Works: Explores as deeply as possible along one branch before backtracking. â–ª Key Feature: Very memory-efficient compared to BFS. Only stores the current path. â–ª Use Cases: â–ª Pathfinding & Mazes: Finding a path from a start to an end point. â–ª Topological Sorting: Scheduling tasks with dependencies (e.g., compiling code). â–ª Cycle Detection: Identifying loops in a graph (critical for dependency management). 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 8 Depth First Search (DFS) â–ª How it Works: Explores as deeply as possible along one branch before backtracking. â–ª Key Feature: Very memory-efficient compared to BFS. Only stores the current path. â–ª Use Cases: â–ª Pathfinding & Mazes: Finding a path from a start to an end point. â–ª Topological Sorting: Scheduling tasks with dependencies (e.g., compiling code). â–ª Cycle Detection: Identifying loops in a graph (critical for dependency management). 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 9 Depth Limited Search (DLS) â–ª How it Works: A standard DFS that stops searching once it reaches a pre-defined depth limit. â–ª Key Feature: Solves the infinite-path problem of DFS in graphs with cycles. â–ª Use Cases: â–ª Game AI: Exploring a game tree up to a certain number of moves ahead (e.g., a chess engine looking 5 moves deep). â–ª Puzzle Solving: Constraining the search space in complex puzzles where a solution is likely within a known depth. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 10 Fig: DLS (with depth limit =2) Iterative Deepening Search (IDS) â–ª How it Works: It performs repeated Depth-Limited Searches, increasing the depth limit with each iteration (1, 2, 3...). Combines BFS and DFS. â–ª Key Feature: The "best of both worlds"â€”finds the optimal solution like BFS while using the low memory of DFS. â–ª Use Cases: â–ª Large Search Spaces: The ideal choice when the search space is huge and the solution depth is unknown. â–ª Game AI: Finds the optimal (shortest) sequence of moves without the massive memory cost of BFS. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 11 Fig: IDS Search Process â–ª A search algorithm takes a search problem as input and returns a solution, or an indication of failure. â–ª Each node in a search tree over state-space search graph forms various paths from initial state. â–ª Each node in a search tree correspond to a state and the edges correspond to an action. â–ª frontier node â–ª interior region vs exterior region 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 12 Search Data structure â–ª node.STATE : the state which the node corresponds â–ª node.PARENT : the node that generated this node during search process. â–ª node.ACTION : the action that was applied to parentâ€™s state to generate this node. â–ª node.PATH_COST : the total cost of the path from initial state to this node, also denoted by g(node) 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 13 Search Data structure â–ª Priority queue: pops the node with minimum coset according to some evaluation function ğ‘“. Used in best-first search â–ª FIFO queue: QUEUE pops the node which was inserted first, used in breadth-first search. â–ª LIFO queue : STACK pops the most recently added node, used in depth-first search. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 14 Measuring Search algorithm performance â–ª C.O.S.T â–ª Completeness: Is the algorithm guaranteed to find a solution when there is one, and to correctly report failure when there is not ? - Clear communication about solution or failure â–ª Optimality: Does it find the a solution with lowest cost of all solutions ? â–ª Space Complexity : How much memory is needed to perform search? â–ª Time Complexity : How long it takes to find a solution? 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 15 Time and space complexity are measured in terms of ï½ï€ b: maximum of the search tree ï½ï€ d: depth of the least-cost branching factor solution. ï½ï€ m: maximum depth of the state space (may be âˆ) BFS algo 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 16 BFS Example 1 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 17 BFS Properties 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 18 â–ªComplete ? â–ªTime ? â–ªSpace ? â–ªOptimal ? .- where b is the branching factor for each node and - d is the maximum depth at which goal state is found BFS Properties 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 19 â–ªComplete? Yes (if b is finite) â–ªTime? O(b^d) [ 1+ b + b^2 + â€¦+ b^d] = O(b^d) â–ªSpace? O(b^d) (keeps every node in memory) â–ªOptimal? Yes (if cost = 1 per step) .- where b is the branching factor for each node and - d is the maximum depth at which goal state is found â–ª BFS always finds a solution with minimum number of actions BFS Properties 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 20 â–ªComplete? Yes (if b is finite) â–ªTime? O(b^d) [ 1+ b + b^2 + â€¦+ b^d] = O(b^d) â–ªSpace? O(b^d) (keeps every node in memory) â–ªOptimal? Yes (if cost = 1 per step) .- where b is the branching factor for each node and - d is the maximum depth at which goal state is found â–ª BFS always finds a solution with minimum number of actions BFS Drawback 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 21 â–ªWhen b=10, and d=10, BFS would take 3 hrs and 10 TB of memory. â–ªWith d=14, search would take 3.5 years even with infinite memory. â–ªExponential complexity search problems can not be solved by uninformed search for any but smallest instance. BFS algo â–ª function BREADTH-FIRST-SEARCH(problem) returns a solution node or failure node â† NODE(problem.INITIAL) if problem.IS-GOAL(node.STATE) then return node frontier â† a FIFO queue, with node as an element reached â† {problem.INITIAL} while not IS-EMPTY(frontier) do node â† POP(frontier) for each child in EXPAND(problem, node) do s â† child.STATE if problem.IS-GOAL(s) then return child â–ª if s is not in reached then â–ª add s to reached â–ª add child to frontier â–ª return failure 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 22 Practice Problem -1 Q1. Apply the following search algorithms to find a path from the node A to G in the given graph: i) Depth First Search (DFS) ii) Depth-limited search (L=2) iii) Iterative Deepening Search (IDS) Note: Process the nodes alphabetically for the nodes at the same level. b) Analyze the above algorithms regarding completeness, optimality, time complexity, and space complexity. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 23 Solution - Practice Problem -1 Solution Q1. i) DFS 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 24 Solution - Practice Problem -1 Solution Q1. ii) DLS 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 25 Solution - Practice Problem -1 Solution Q1. iii) IDS 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 26 Solution - Practice Problem -1 Solution Q1. iii) IDS 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 27 Solution - Practice Problem -1 Solutn Q1. 7/31/2025 Dr. Durgesh Kumar, AI (BCSE306) 28 Practice Problem -2 Q2.
